title: The Best Homemade Cat Sprays to Keep Cats from Scratching

steps.title: Add vinegar and water to a spray bottle in a 1:1 ratio.
steps.content: Add vinegar and water to a spray bottle in a 1:1 ratio. For this homemade cat repellent, you’ll need a spray bottle. Pour 1 part white vinegar and 1 part water into the bottle, and swish them together quickly to blend them. [1] X Research source You can use tap, filtered, purified, or bottled water for this repellent. A plastic or glass spray bottle works perfectly for this recipe. This homemade cat repellent is considered the safest option, as it doesn’t require any potentially toxic essential oils or fragrances.

steps.title: Add liquid hand soap to the bottle and shake well.
steps.content: Add liquid hand soap to the bottle and shake well. When the vinegar and water are mixed, squeeze 1 squirt of liquid hand soap into the spray bottle. Shake the mixture vigorously to ensure that the soap is fully combined with the vinegar mixture. [2] X Research source Any type of hand soap will work for the repellent, but it’s best to use a clear formula.

steps.title: Spray or wipe the mixture where you want to repel cats.
steps.content: Spray or wipe the mixture where you want to repel cats. Once the vinegar, water, and soap are fully mixed together, apply the repellent to the areas where you want to discourage cats from going. You can spray it directly from the bottle or apply it to a cloth and wipe it over the spots. [3] X Research source Use this repellent to keep cats away from both indoor and outdoor locations. Just be careful with fabrics, as the vinegar might stain.

steps.title: Boil 2 cups (473 ml) of water.
steps.content: Boil 2 cups (473 ml) of water. Add 2 cups (473 ml) of water to a medium pot. Heat the water over medium-high to high heat until it boils , which typically takes around 5-7 minutes. [4] X Research source Tap water is perfectly fine to use for this repellent.

steps.title: Mix in 1 cup (96 g) of citrus peels and simmer the mixture.
steps.content: Mix in 1 cup (96 g) of citrus peels and simmer the mixture. Once the water comes to a boil, add 1 cup (96 g) of orange, lemon, lime, and/or tangerine peels to the pot. Lower the heat to medium and let the mixture simmer for 20 minutes. [5] X Research source Cats dislike citrus scents, so any combination of orange, lemon, lime, and/or tangerine peels that totals a cup (96 g) will work well! [6] X Research source

steps.title: Allow the mixture to cool and transfer it to a spray bottle.
steps.content: Allow the mixture to cool and transfer it to a spray bottle. After the mixture has simmered for 20 minutes, take the pot off the heat. Let the mixture cool completely, which should take approximately 30 minutes, before transferring it to a spray bottle. [7] X Research source If the citrus peels are in large chunks, strain them out of the mixture so it’s easier to pour into the bottle.

steps.title: Add 2 teaspoons (10 ml) of lemon juice and dish soap and shake well.
steps.content: Add 2 teaspoons (10 ml) of lemon juice and dish soap and shake well. Once you’ve transferred the mixture into the spray bottle, pour 2 teaspoons (10 ml) of lemon juice and a squirt or two of citrus-scented dish soap . Shake the bottle well to ensure that all of the ingredients are well combined. [8] X Research source Using a citrus-scented soap adds an extra layer of scent that cats will be deterred from. You can substitute lime or orange juice for the lemon, but be sure to use freshly squeezed juice.

steps.title: Apply the mixture to floors, walls, and furniture.
steps.content: Apply the mixture to floors, walls, and furniture. After you’ve thoroughly mixed the ingredients, spray the mixture in any area of your house that you want to keep cats out of. You can apply it to floors, walls, and even furniture. [9] X Research source To be safe, test the repellent on an inconspicuous spot on a fabric-covered item to ensure that the ingredients won’t damage the material.

steps.title: Fill a glass spray bottle with water.
steps.content: Fill a glass spray bottle with water. Add enough water to a glass spray bottle until the water is almost at the very top. Be sure to leave an inch or so of space so the repellent does spill over when you screw on the cap. [10] X Research source Tap, filtered, purified, and bottled water will all work for this repellent. Citronella and other essential oils can break down plastic, which is why it’s best to use a glass spray bottle. [11] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source

steps.title: Add 20 drops of citronella oil to the bottle and shake well.
steps.content: Add 20 drops of citronella oil to the bottle and shake well. After you’ve nearly filled the bottle with water, squeeze 20 drops of citronella oil into it. Mix the oil into the water by shaking the bottle well. [12] X Research source Citronella oil has an extremely strong odor that repels cats. It is also effective in keeping insects away.

steps.title: Spray the mixture in indoor and outdoor locations.
steps.content: Spray the mixture in indoor and outdoor locations. Once you’ve mixed the citronella oil and water thoroughly, apply the mixture to any areas you want to keep cats away from. Use this repellent indoors and outdoors. [13] X Research source For the best results, spray this repellent on areas where cats have peed in your yard. Make sure to clean the area well before spraying. If you use this repellent outdoors, be sure to reapply it if it rains.

steps.title: Add the essential oil to a spray bottle.
steps.content: Add the essential oil to a spray bottle . For the repellent, you’ll need a 2-ounce (59 ml) glass spray bottle. Squeeze 2 drops of lemon essential oil , 2 drops of wild orange essential oil , and 2 drops of lavender essential oil into the bottle. [14] X Research source Cats are more sensitive to scents than humans, so essential oils with strong odors, such as citrus and lavender, can help repel them. You can substitute lime, peppermint, and/or eucalyptus oils in this recipe if you prefer. It’s important to use a glass bottle for the spray because essential oils degrade more easily in plastic. [15] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source Warning: Essential oils can be toxic and poisonous to cats. While the oils may deter cats, if they’re not diluted, they could be very harmful and cause liver failure, seizures, or death. Use them with caution. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Fill the spray bottle with water and shake it well to mix.
steps.content: Fill the spray bottle with water and shake it well to mix. After you’ve added the essential oils to the spray bottle, pour enough water into it to fill it. Close the bottle securely, and shake well to ensure that the oils are blended with the water. [17] X Research source It isn’t necessary to use filtered or purified water for the spray. Regular tap water works fine.

steps.title: Spray the mixture where you’d like to keep cats away.
steps.content: Spray the mixture where you’d like to keep cats away. Once the water and oils are mixed, apply the cat repellent to areas that you want to discourage cats from visiting. In particular, it works well if you have house plants that you want to keep cats away from. [18] X Research source As Bensinger advises, be careful spraying the repellent on carpeting, curtains, or other fabrics, as the oils may stain the material. Test the spray on an inconspicuous spot on the fabric to ensure it won’t damage the fabric.

steps.title: Combine pepper, mustard, and cinnamon in a small spray bottle.
steps.content: Combine pepper, mustard, and cinnamon in a small spray bottle. For this cat repellent, you’ll need a 2-ounce (59 ml) glass spray bottle. Add 1 teaspoon (2 g) of black pepper, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of dry mustard, and 1 teaspoon (3 g) of cinnamon to the bottle. [19] X Research source You can substitute the black pepper with cayenne pepper if you prefer. Warning: This homemade repellent can get smelly, so it’s best for outdoor use.

steps.title: Add a few drops of lemon oil and a crushed garlic clove.
steps.content: Add a few drops of lemon oil and a crushed garlic clove. After you’ve added the spices to the spray bottle, toss in a crushed garlic clove. Next, squeeze in 3 to 4 drops of lemon essential oil, and swish the contents gently to combine. [20] X Research source If you don’t have a garlic clove, substitute with ⅛ teaspoon (½ g) of garlic powder. Lime, wild orange, or grapefruit essential oil can also work in place of lemon oil. Warning: Essential oils can be toxic and poisonous to cats. While the oils may deter cats, if they’re not diluted, they could be very harmful and cause liver failure, seizures, or death. Use them with caution. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Fill the bottle with water and mix well.
steps.content: Fill the bottle with water and mix well. Once all of the spices and oil are in the bottle, add enough water to fill the container. Shake the bottle vigorously to completely blend all of the ingredients. [22] X Research source Make sure to leave some space at the top of the bottle so the repellent doesn’t spill out when you screw on the top.

steps.title: Apply the mixture to preferred outdoor areas.
steps.content: Apply the mixture to preferred outdoor areas. When the spray is fully mixed, spray it over any outdoor areas you want to keep cats away from. This repellent works best in garden beds and on bushes and other plants. [23] X Research source Similarly, you can also use the repellent to keep cats away from indoor plants.

steps.title: Prevent cats from scratching with natural deterrents.
steps.content: Prevent cats from scratching with natural deterrents. Scratching is a natural, instinctive behavior for cats. They scratch because they’re sharpening their claws or trying to communicate. In the wild, this isn’t a problem, but it can be quite destructive indoors, especially for your furniture. Luckily, there are ways to help draw your cat’s focus elsewhere. Here’s how you can stop cats from scratching furniture : [24] X Research source Place a scratching post near the area the cat is scratching. Invest in a durable scratching post with a strong base and tall pole. Purchase a scratching pad for a cat that likes to scratch horizontally. Place catnip on scratching posts or pads to encourage scratching. [25] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source Discourage scratching by moving the scratched item or using a deterring spray. Stick double-sided tape on favored surfaces to protect them and deter scratching. Protect furniture with thick, shiny plastic.

steps.title: Keep cats away with smells, sprinklers, and other humane measures.
steps.content: Keep cats away with smells, sprinklers, and other humane measures. Having stray or unwanted cats coming into your yard or peeing on your things can be frustrating. Thankfully, they’re are ways to deter them naturally without harming them. Here are the top ways you can deter cats from coming into your space: [26] X Research source Plant herbs or spray scents of citrus, garlic, ammonia, vinegar, coffee, citronella, and/or eucalyptus in your garden. Place motion-activated sprinklers on your lawn. Secure any outdoor trash in closed or locked bins. Place plastic mats with flexible spikes to discourage digging. Put pine cones or lava rocks in outdoor potted plants to discourage digging.
